text: Number 493, J. L. Enochs, District Director of Internal Revenue, Petitioner, versus Williams Packing and Navigation Company, Incorporated.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
This (Inaudible) that issue the tax itself to promote?
No Mr. Justice Harlan and I know how interested the Court is in -- in the administrative practice with respect to an issue and I've defined in our brief, did not include a published ruling.
The -- it's Volume 1 of the 19 -- Section 1 of the 1940 Volume of Cumulative Bulletin published by the Internal Revenue Service.
And the page?
And the page is 192.
(Inaudible)
It's involved -- it is involved ultimately in this sense only, Mr. Justice Brenan.
Is there any question about that as being available?
Back to the right to sue for refund?
Perhaps a quarter or something like that.
For a quarter or for a year.
Is that an adjudicated in Flora, --
No sir.
Mr. Oberdorfer?
Not to my knowledge Justice Brennan.
What was the basis -- that was the basis below that there was no employee relationship, there's been no finding in this case?
There has been such a finding.
And that there was no employee relationship.
That's correct sir.
And on that premise, the Government still insists that believe by way of injunction is not available.
Yes sir.
Mr. Oberdorfer.
Yes sir.

-- I understood that the respondents said they were taken by surprise in this matter that they -- that the administrative practice was contrary to this regulation that you mentioned and that they -- they had never been required to pay this tax until after their -- after the antitrust suit against the -- against the seamen and as if wondering why that was the practice since 1940 that they only knew about it, at that late date.

Mr. Chief Justice, I -- it's -- it is conceivable -- quite conceivable to me that this taxpayer as a matter of fact hadn't thought he owed the tax or had -- it hadn't occurred to him that he owed tax.

Well, I -- I -- I thought also that the position of the parties is reversed in this case that in the antitrust case, I understood that they claim they were employees and therefore they were not violating antitrust and the Government contended that they were -- that they were not and now the situation is exactly reversed.
Mr. Chief Justice, in the antitrust case, the -- the defendant was a -- a -- really an -- an association of --
Yes.
-- of fisherman sort of the labor union.
Yes.
And they asserted a defense that the antitrust action couldn't lie because of the Norris-LaGuardia provisions or because there was a -- because it was a labor dispute.
What was the legislative history show since that decision, the Margarine decision?
The --
Have the reports throw any light upon it?
No sir and --
I noticed that the wording isn't quite the same (Voice Overlap) --
The -- the wording -- the changes in the wording don't -- don't mean anything to us.
No, very irrelevant to this problem.
Yes sir.
But they came in since the --
No sudden changes.
Yes.

But the Congress is certainly -- if you wanted to say it, you could -- if -- if you could say that the Congress has embraced the -- the Nut Margarine rule by reenacting the Internal Revenue Code over these years.

Mr. Oberdorfer, before I forget it and because it isn't in your brief, I wonder if you would submit a short memorandum concerning this -- this regulation that you have mentioned, 387 and -- and also the administrative practice under it and counsel you may reply to it of course.
Thank you Your Honor.
Mr. Morse.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
If we accept that fact, is that all there is to the case (Voice Overlap) --
No sir that is not because I'll proceed to the next point and that is an equitable consideration which was considered by the Court in the Miller case.
As I understood --
Sir?
-- Mr. Oberdorfer have suggested that perhaps the Flora rule would not apply to this kind of facts, maybe something less than --
Well, I say and we discuss in our brief this Flora case, this footnote.
Didn't he initiate (Inaudible).
No, sir.
I thought you did a moment ago.
Sir, I'm speaking -- I thought you -- of the trial as it proceeded.
And do you take what Mr. Oberdorfer said a few minutes ago as the indication at least that you could pay a quarter and --
Well, I take it sir that Mr. Oberdorfer and I recall his statement on that.
Is there a -- has the company paid any of the tax?
Sir?
You haven't paid any of the tax?
No, sir, the tax has not been paid.
You're in the same position when we started except the crew since that time, is that right?
That's right, sir.
You were not a party to the --
Sir?
-- antitrust suit?
No, sir, that, we were not.
Yes.
However, as I point out in our brief, the president of the respondent here was called as a witness to testify before the grand jury which ultimately indicted the union.
What year is that?
Sir?
What year is the antitrust?
The antitrust case, as I recall, occurred about 1953.
There was the added factor in -- in the Nut Margarine case was there not?
That is true, the Government had loss.
Mr. Morse.
Yes sir.

Wouldn't it be a rather late restriction on 7421 (a) that -- that any taxpayer could go into Court to merely claim that this tax was illegally assessed and that it would bankrupt him if he had -- had to pay it and then be entitled to a preliminary injunction to prevent the commissioner from collecting it?
I think it -- I agree with the Court that it would and it has been attempted many times and in some cases, particularly social security case -- cases.
Very well.
I have nothing more Your Honor unless there are questions.
Very well.
